awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021: Investigating the role of ARGONAUTE and small RNAs in heritable stress memory in plants
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2021, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the Fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. This research seeks to understand how plants interpret environmental stress signals and how these signals are transmitted across generations. Plants have evolved complex mechanisms to tolerate recurring stress and can prime their offspring for subsequent stresses. Investigating how this transmission occurs is important to advancing scientific knowledge and provides societal benefits because understanding how plants can adapt rapidly to stressful environments, such as climate change effects, helps to mitigate challenges to food security. The Fellow will use classical genetics and genomics techniques to investigate how epigenetic regulation, the control of gene expression, affects the ability of plants to form stress memories and transmit stress-induced epigenetic changes to offspring. Given the relevance of the study to agriculture, the Fellow will explain the work to audiences of diverse backgrounds through public-facing science communication, outreach, and teaching. 

The study will focus on small RNA biology and the role of ARGONAUTE proteins, a highly-conserved yet functionally-diverse family of small RNA silencing effectors. There are 10 ARGONAUTEs in Arabidopsis, each providing unique and overlapping functions through interactions with small RNAs and co-factors. ARGONAUTEs are the gate-keepers of small RNA-mediated gene silencing because all small RNAs are dependent on their interaction with ARGONAUTE to target complementary messenger RNA and/or DNA for silencing. Small RNA-ARGONAUTE interactions are necessary for proper development, defense against viruses, responding to environmental stresses, and epigenetic regulation in the germline, as expression of several ARGONAUTEs are restricted to reproductive tissues. Adding to this complexity, pseudouridine-modified small RNAs are enriched in the germline which may alter small RNA-ARGONAUTE interactions and therefore affect epigenetic inheritance. Pseudouridine-modified RNAs are dynamic under heat stress in yeast, but they have yet to be characterized in plant stress memory. This research will dissect the function of germline ARGONAUTEs and pseudouridine RNA in stress memory formation and inheritance in plants by analyzing loss-of-function mutants paired with epigenomic profiling. The Fellow will receive expert training in these areas at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory as well as from their world-renowned courses. Broadening participation efforts will include outreach and teaching about epigenetic regulation and biotechnology at the DNA Learning Center in New York City.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
My NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology focused on unraveling the intricate connections between plant stress responses, RNA interference (RNAi), and heritable memory mechanisms, as part of the project titled "Investigating the role of ARGONAUTE and small RNAs in heritable stress memory in plants" (Federal Award ID: 2109794). This fellowship provided me with a unique opportunity to further our understanding of how plants utilize ARGONAUTE (AGO) proteins to adapt to stress, how this adaptation is epigenetically regulated, and the broader implications of AGO regulation on the epigenetic landscape within and across generations.

A pivotal aspect of my research involved developing a sensitive and reliable assay for evaluating plant tolerance to moderately high temperatures. This fellowship allowed me to carefully select experimental growth conditions that produced variable survival rates in RNA interference (RNAi) mutants, providing the foundation for an in-depth investigation into AGO-mediated heat stress responses and their transgenerational implications. Throughout these investigations I made intriguing and unexpected discoveries. Notably, I revealed the presence of redundancy between AGO2 and AGO3 in the context of heat stress, a finding that challenged prior research, which had indicated no redundancy. This context specific epistasis helped to reveal an unforeseen role for AGO2 and AGO3 in balancing transcriptional and post-transcriptional gene regulation, a feature that appears to be conserved between Arabidopsis and maize. Furthermore, the results hinted at the existence of RNA interference (RNAi) compensation, where mutations in one AGO led to increased protein levels of other AGOs, potentially interacting with wandering small interfering RNAs (siRNAs) that lack their main binding partner in the mutant background.

Besides the major findings described above, the results from work performed during this fellowship are poised to provide illuminating answers and important resources. As part of determining the mechanism behind AGO2/3-dependent heat stress sensitivity, higher-order AGO-epigenetic regulator mutant collections in Arabidopsis were generated, providing valuable insights into redundancy and epistasis across transcriptional gene silencing (TGS) and post-transcriptional gene silencing (PTGS). In addition, a comprehensive RNA-seq dataset from the heat stress time course was generated. This dataset was comprised of 60 samples spanning diverse environmental conditions and genotypes and will shed light on the role of AGO2 and AGO3 in TGS/PTGS balance and the heat stress response. In the context of maize, this fellowship allowed me to develop skill in CRISPR-Cas9 genome editing which I used to create novel mutant alleles in AGO PIWI domains from four different maize AGO genes. Subsequent crosses were carried out to explore the roles of these mutants in transgenerational epigenetic inheritance, specifically within the b1 paramutation system.

This fellowship has not only allowed me to advance my research and training but has also enabled active participation in social-scientific activities tied to my academic interests. Over the course of this fellowship, I engaged in five scientific meetings, including presenting my work at the Maize Genetic Conference in March of 2023, and extended these scientific pursuits to broader impact initiatives. These activities involved developing the Maize Genetics Mentorship Program as a part of the Maize Membership Committee, along with leading an annual virtual career development workshop series. Notably, this fellowship afforded me the opportunity to assume pivotal roles, serving as both the treasurer and chair of the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Postdoctoral Liaison committee. In these capacities, I effectively advocated for postdoctoral concerns and played an instrumental role in nurturing a supportive scientific community. Throughout the fellowship, I co-authored four primary research articles and one review article, all of which are either in press or available as a preprint. Through these various means I believe that my fellowship has given me the opportunity to communicate my science and contribute to advancing scientific knowledge within the field.

In conclusion, the NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology has been a transformative journey of scientific exploration and discovery for me. This award not only provided me with crucial training resources but also the invaluable opportunity to conduct groundbreaking research, characterized by unexpected twists and turns. My findings have deepened our understanding of the roles of ARGONAUTE proteins and small RNAs in plant stress responses and epigenetic regulation. Furthermore, this fellowship has allowed me to make significant contributions to advancing the NSF's broader participation objectives. With unwavering dedication and enthusiasm, I am poised to continue unraveling the mysteries of epigenetics and to share these discoveries with the broader public and scientific community.
